comments.commentBody: Not so sure about that.  Better for many to provide training in a trade -- won't we always need sklled electricians, plumbers, carpenters?  These days they are more useful than many college grads.

The real divide isn't blue or white collar, or free 4 year college or otherwise. The divide is between productive labor that is capable of providing useful services the economy needs at a high rate of productivity vs. labor that can't do so. For example, There are many 4 year educated people (say, English majors, Sociology majors etc) who cannot find meaningful employment while  a 2 year college well qualified nurse can start out in the mid 50k and above.

Blue collar workers are better equipped to start their own business since they are the most valuable asset. I started one with everything crammed into an old Chevrolet Chevette and saved for my first truck. I cold called and rounded up customers. But most of all I had me and my skills. I've never seen a plumbing contractor who was poor, nor an electrical contractor. Even the guy who built my custom cabinets seemed to be doing well. The ones who last aso learned the system. If they didn't they hired the people who did. A Lawyer, accountant, etc. They might be good at their trades but recognize that they don't know it all. They kept up with new product offerings and new methods. They talked with customers to see what they wanted and figured out how to get it for them. They learned how to fire time sucking money losing "customers and employees. And a lot of us have a high school education or a GED. Many of us are military veterans who learned a trade in the service/ ( I was a SEABEE) We do the work the college educated people won't do and get paid well for it. I'll crawl through sewage for $145 an hour any day.

Today, if you are a blue collar worker, it is a very crowded field where the supply greatly exceeds the demand. American dream is dead not for everyone but mostly for the blue collar workers. As our economy evolves, its demand for blue collar workers lessens. To prepare our economy for the 21st century, our first step is to  make 4-year college compulsory and free to all so we can eventually have a labor force that is ready for the 21st Century.

Robert: the banking sector today is unrecognizable from what existed 32 years ago. In 1982, banks weren't too big to fail. Banks were regional, not national. Glass-St. still in force. We hadn't experience three financial-based recessions, culminating in the first full-scale financial panic. We had a vibrant S&L industry, and banks weren't involved with mortgages. The Fed and other regulators hadn't lost control of major financial segments. Japan had most of the largest banks in the world. The Euro didn't exist.

Since 12/1947, the monthly rate of inflation from one year prior has exceeded 3.5% in 322 months. This is to say inflation has been the state of affairs about 40% of the time since 12/1947. If inflation were bad for banks and banks were not too big to fail why weren't there more bank failures prior to 2008? Where is the evidence that inflation harms banks?

These entities are positioned for this to occur as part of their trading strategies; they do take risk in their management of their portfolios, which is why they take huge profits out of the flow of these markets. Completely wrong about the inflation point, is what I meant to imply.

An entity who is holding such debt-based assets for holding sake should have distributed their positions, and they should hold a low % in financial assets that, may be safe, but earn low rates of return if held to maturity.

I think you are just thinking too narrowly, as if these instruments are just for holding purposes.

And as you note above, one of the changes since 1982 then also saw acceleration in the huge trading marketplaces and a drop in a culture of prudent behavior as we'd understand the word. They want volatility and would love it if the FRB started it all by increasing policy rates (for some reason). Let us hope the FRB does this because they see evidence in the marketplace not because they have lost their independence.

And boy, do I not feel sorry for the inflation fear-sellers who may have lost lots of money on huge trading blocs (not talking about regular people here) based on getting this to happen over the last 6-7 years - rent-seekers we don't want, prudent portfolio managers, OK.

What is more important a consideration than weighing the risks and damage from too easy money or too tight? I'll tell you. It's the power and influence from the financial sector who stand to lose from high inflation vs. the lack of power and influence of those who'll lose their jobs, homes, and retirement savings if we plunge into an endless series of recessions, a la Japan and Europe. That's what is behind the current pressure on the Fed.

It isn't that the older professors "refuse to retire."  It's that more and more endowment goes into coaches' and administrators' salaries.  In 40 states, a university coach is the highest paid public employee.  My fatal mistake was returning to academia, which had provided a decent middle-class living to four generations of my ancestors.  So little grant money goes to individual researchers, and on so unpredictable a schedule, that most researchers will be indigent when they retire.

The comment from the retired social studies teacher seems a bit cavalier. Does Mr. Monti realize what is happening in academia these days? Among younger people, those with even PhDs in political science and/or history, which correspond roughly to the subject matter that he taught, are offered jobs in the sub $40,000 range these days, as "visiting" professors, or worse, as post-docs, or, worse still, as adjuncts. The older professors often refuse to retire to make room for the younger, limiting amounts available to hire new faculty, and seem to have basically thrown the latter under the bus.

Intergenerational inequity in wages is very unwise, in my opinion, as the powers that be will start to question why someone who retired from a particular career should have a pension that is likely more than twice what newer hires doing the same job are making, and those who have no hope of a reasonable pension will balk at continuing to fund generous pensions for others.

You're missing one piece: the filter-down effect. The person near the bottom end of the hiring chain isn't rejecting offers; s/he isn't getting any. And if I'm a few rungs up (say, earning $50K per annum), then I'm not going anywhere unless I see an offer for $55K or $60K. But if I get that, then my old job is open for someone who may have been earning only $40K or so. And so on down the line. "From here on, it's all turtles."

Several thoughts:
1. Wages are so poor in this corporation-dominated country that plenty of workers want and deserve $10,000 or $20,000 higher than what they're offered, not $2,000
2. The opportunity cost of that $20,000 job is probably temporary or under-the-table or part-time work/leisure/education time that is preferable as a stopgap, and lots of people would rather do that while they wait.
3. People have dignity and don't want to (and shouldn't have to) take huge pay cuts and cuts in the integrity of their work packages in new jobs. Catastrophic national and corporate leadership caused a huge recession, not average workers. I can understand not wanting to pick up the pieces in one's own life with a worse job.

What is being said here is that workers aren't taking jobs that don't pay enough by their measure and are waiting until wages increase to work again. That makes no economic sense.

Here's why, say a job offers $20000 but the worker thinks it should pay $22000 and so waits until it rises. A year from now it does and he takes it. To make up for the $20000 he didn't earn he now has to work for over ten years at $22000 to break even. If he had taken the job at $20000, a year later he would have likely been given a raise to $22000 if the employer wanted to retain him. Even if he didn't get the whole $2000 increase he's still financially way more ahead than if he had been unemployed for that year.

It is always better to be employed, even if underpaid, than to be unemployed.

This thinking also generally holds true when collecting Social Security. It generally makes more sense to start taking SS as early as you can rather than giving up current income for greater payments a few years down the road. This is true unless one lives a really long time.

I do interval workouts every other day. One day of weights, one day of cardio for 5_6 days per week.  I do  30 seconds of intervals. With one minute of rest, 7 times, after my normal cardio workout of 35_45 minutes. I'm 74 yrs old, and feel great. I don't believe you can get the same benefits. Doing 1 or2  minutes per day wont do it for you.

It's possible to have fun while getting a short burst of high energy exercise.  Every morning I take our whippet-cross for a walk and at the far end of our route we play a game.  Each of us tries to get behind the other by feinting from side to side and sprinting.  Neither of us ever succeeds but after twenty seconds of trying to outflank a fast dog I'm exhausted, she's delighted and I can feel my mitochondria reproducing.

Its always very complicated. There are no answers for people who ask how various commodity prices will work through the economy. Prices under long term contracts are usually not reflected in news worthy spot market prices. Many intervening considerations distort the relationship between commodity prices and final consumer goods. Deflation is caused by too many goods chasing too few dollars. Inflation results from too many dollars chasing to few goods. Aggregate demand differs from aggregate supply and the CPI changes. Particular commodity prices soar or crash and relative prices change but those changes might have ambiguous links to the CPI because it depends on aggregate demand.

What about futures contracts?  How much of today's commodities used in production is embedded in futures contracts?  I'm sure that today's volatility in commodity and energy markets wouldn't alter any current trajectories.  Especially if the economy is beginning to accelerate.

Let us re-say some of this:

deflation is caused by lack of demand so prices then need to drop in order to sell current production, this can lead to a spiraling downward, reactionary-trend for both prices and production

unnatural inflation is caused by sellers having control over pricing, this leads to prices increasing and distorts supply and demand signals across the economy

'natural' price rises across an economy stem from increasing demand that over-strips supplies until bottlenecks are cleared initially by the increased prices and then by a natural match with expanded production

We don't want deflation and we don't want unnatural pricing controls to be the general state of the economy. Note that 'natural' price increases occur in all growing, dynamic economies with positive signals being sent about production needs, and this is what is desired.

The rapid change in oil prices will be unsettling and affect economic signals across the economy. Obviously it should lead to more demand initially as people have more funds freed-up at the pump. The economy for produced goods will be affected by lower production costs, we need to watch this unfold. If this diminishes sellers' control over prices this can slow down natural price rises from increased demand.

I am still wrestling with the problem of understanding how lower energy prices will filter through the US economy into the prices of everything else. Yes, it's true that changes in volatile commodity prices are properly disregarded when computing the general level of price inflation. But commodity prices do filter through production and eventually into everything else. Right now the effect of the bear market in crude oil looks to cause weakness in supply-push inflation. But lower prices paid for energy by consumers looks to strengthen demand-pull inflation. Which effect will be stronger?

The dollar is in a mad rush higher, which is deflationary for domestic prices, especially since major foreign suppliers are already experiencing slowdowns of their own. Copper and iron are very weak.

A lot of things are going on at the same time.This is a particularly bad time for ideological arguments to tighten, "just because", to resurface.
